description: From Middle English discoveren, from Old French descovrir, from Late Latin discoperīre < discooperiō, discooperīre, from Latin dis- + cooperiō. Displaced native Old English onfindan.

verbs.description: discover (third-person singular simple present discovers, present participle discovering, simple past and past participle discovered)

entries.meaning: To find or learn something for the first time.
examples: Turning the corner, I discovered a lovely little shop. I discovered that they sold widgets.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To remove the cover from; to uncover (a head, building etc.).

examples: The gust of wind discovered a bone in the sand.

entries.meaning: (transitive, chess) To create by moving a piece out of another piece's line of attack.
examples: This move discovers an attack on a vital pawn.

entries.meaning: (law, transitive) To question (a person) as part of discovery in a lawsuit.
(transitive, archaic) To reveal (information); to divulge, make known.
examples: I discovered my plans to the rest of the team.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To manifest without design; to show; to exhibit.
examples: The youth discovered a taste for sculpture.
